'Annite' is a phyllosilicate mineral in the mica family. It has a chemical
formula of KFe 32+ AlSi 3O 10 (OH,-
F) 2. Annite is the iron end member of the biotite mica
group, the iron rich analogue of magnesium rich phlogopite. Deer, W. A., R.
A. Howie and Zussman, J., An Introduction to the Rock Forming Minerals, Longman,
1966, p. 212 ISBN 0-582-44210-9 Annite is monoclinic and contains tabular
crystals and cleavage fragments with pseudohexagonal outlines. Kwak, T.A.P.
and Askins, P.W. (1981), Geology of Gneiss of the F-Sn-W (-Be_Zn) skarn
(wrigglite) at Moina, Tasmania, Economical Geology, 76, 439-476 There are
contact twins with composition surface {001} and twin axis
{310}. Anthony,J.W., Bideaux, R.A., Bladh, K.W., and Nichols, C.M. (1995),
Handbook of Mineralogy, Volume II, Silica, Silicates Part 1, p. 31

Annite was first described in 1868 for the first noted occurrence in Cape Ann,
Rockport, Essex County, Massachusetts, US. It also occurs on
Pikes Peak, El Paso County, Colorado. It occurs in igneous and
metamorphic rocks that are deficient in magnesium. It occurs associated with
fluorite and zircon in the type locality.
